tab_content.accordion_title: Can I talk to a doctor on Maple about my hypoglycemia?
tab_content.accordion_intro: Yes. In most cases, a doctor on Maple can help you manage previously diagnosed hypoglycemia. They can prescribe medications and advise on treatment plans.

tab_content.accordion_title: Can I get a prescription on Maple?
tab_content.accordion_intro:
Yes, our physicians can prescribe medications online during your consultation. Once you accept a prescription, you’ll have the option to pick it up from any pharmacy or to have it delivered right to your door at no additional cost.

You can visit our How it Works page to learn more.

Hypoglycemia is a condition that occurs when blood sugar (glucose) levels become low. Hypoglycemia is often (though not always) related to diabetes treatment, but can be caused by a number of other things.

tab_content.accordion_title: What are the types of hypoglycemia?
tab_content.accordion_intro:
There are a few types of hypoglycemia. The most common type of hypoglycemia is diabetic hypoglycemia, which occurs when the medications used to treat diabetes lower a patient’s blood sugar too much. 

There are two types of non-diabetic hypoglycemia:

  • Reactive hypoglycemia, which occurs within a few hours of a meal
  • Fasting hypoglycemia, which may be related to an underlying disease

tab_content.accordion_title: What are the symptoms of hypoglycemia?
tab_content.accordion_intro:
Hypoglycemia symptoms include:

  • An irregular heart rhythm
  • Fatigue
  • Pale skin
  • Shakiness
  • Anxiety
  • Sweating
  • Hunger
  • Irritability
  • Tingling sensation around the mouth
  • Crying out while asleep
tab_content.accordion_content:
As symptoms worsen, so can symptoms such as:

  • Confusion, abnormal behaviour or both; an inability to complete routine tasks
  • Visual disturbances, blurred vision
  • Slurred words
  • Clumsiness
  • Seizures
  • Loss of consciousness

tab_content.accordion_intro: If you have diabetic hypoglycemia, this is usually caused by your medication lowering your blood sugar too much. It can also happen if you haven’t eaten enough after taking your medication or if you exercise more than normal. Non-diabetic hypoglycemia has a number of causes, including medications, excessive alcohol consumption, kidney disorders, long-term starvation, liver disease, pancreatic disease, and hormone deficiencies. People who have had stomach surgery sometimes have reactive hypoglycemia, which occurs after a meal.

Hypoglycemia treatment involves a two-pronged approach: immediate treatment to raise blood sugar and treating the underlying condition. Initial symptoms can often be treated easily by consuming 15-20 grams of fast-acting carbohydrates, such as fruit juice, sugary candy, and regular soft drinks. If symptoms become severe, you may need injections of glucagon (if you have frequent bouts of hypoglycemia, you can get an at-home glucagon kit), or intravenous infusions of glucose.
tab_content.accordion_content: Depending on the cause of your hypoglycemia, you may have to adjust medication dosage or change medications, address anorexia, and/or treat tumors. Essentially, once the underlying cause is treated, the hypoglycemia should resolve as well.
